content.body: If word order is important, then it's unavoidable that we will have libraries explicitly written to allow "method-chaining"-ish (aka "fluent API") calling, using the operator.
that's fine

but the intended use case still needs them
our job is explicitly not to be paternalistic
if people want to do gross things, we have to let them (in some ways)

content.body: I don't understand why call-this is taken as a viable alternative to bind-op.
It's the less fluent choice, because we don't want to promote a code style.
let me state my opinion more strongly: muggles (devs who aren't deep into language minutiae) *will never* prefer writing functions that use `this` solely because they can use it with `::`
content.formatted_body: let me state my opinion more strongly: muggles (devs who aren't deep into language minutiae) will never prefer writing functions that use this solely because they can use it with ::

content.body: it just won't happen
certainly some rebels will try to do something terrible and clever with that approach! but that doesn't mean it'll go anywhere
i've seen a whole lot of bind and call

i mean given
```
arr
  .slice(…)
  .flat(…)
  ::somethingNew(…)
  .filter(…)
```
vs
```
arr
  .slice(…)
  .flat(…)
  |> somethingNew@(#, …)
  .filter(…)
```

the former is clearly better to me.

content.body: I think both of those are undesirable, honestly

Justin Ridgewell: So, right, call-this is intentionally not as "fluent" as bind-this in the .call() case, specifically to avoid overlapping with pipeline. It achieves the functionality (terse, reliable .call()) without anything else. Self-binding (aka method extraction) is imo best done by PFA; `obj.method~()` is clearly better than `obj::obj.method`, imo.  Other-binding is the final leftover case, but I think this is (a) the least common of these cases, afaict from the collected data and (b) sufficiently okay to just use arrow functions with - `that=>slice@(that, 0, 2)` seems fine for this.
content.formatted_body: Justin Ridgewell: So, right, call-this is intentionally not as "fluent" as bind-this in the .call() case, specifically to avoid overlapping with pipeline. It achieves the functionality (terse, reliable .call()) without anything else. Self-binding (aka method extraction) is imo best done by PFA; obj.method~() is clearly better than obj::obj.method, imo. Other-binding is the final leftover case, but I think this is (a) the least common of these cases, afaict from the collected data and (b) sufficiently okay to just use arrow functions with - that=>slice@(that, 0, 2) seems fine for this.

content.body: and i'm quite certain the pipeline one would look horrendous

In my opinion, if someone goes through the trouble of setting a local variable like `slice` that they can use as a function, it's approximately as much effort to import it as an unbound function as it is to destructure it from Array.prototype (or []). For something like slice, I'd expect that some coders would use a bound version while others would use unbound since it's up to the user to choose which way to do it. Especially if this-calls are introduced after pipelines. For something like RxJs, it's different of course.
content.formatted_body: In my opinion, if someone goes through the trouble of setting a local variable like slice that they can use as a function, it's approximately as much effort to import it as an unbound function as it is to destructure it from Array.prototype (or []). For something like slice, I'd expect that some coders would use a bound version while others would use unbound since it's up to the user to choose which way to do it. Especially if this-calls are introduced after pipelines. For something like RxJs, it's different of course.
